metadata.title: Synonymous mutations and the molecular evolution of SARS-Cov-2 origins

abstract.text: Human severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is most closely 2 related, by average genetic distance, to two coronaviruses isolated from bats, RaTG13 and 3 RmYN02. However, there is a segment of high amino acid similarity between human SARS-4

CoV-2 and a pangolin isolated strain, GD410721, in the receptor binding domain (RBD) of 5 the spike protein, a pattern that can be caused by either recombination or by convergent 6 amino acid evolution driven by natural selection. We perform a detailed analysis of the 7 synonymous divergence, which is less likely to be affected by selection than amino acid 8 divergence, between human SARS-CoV-2 and related strains. We show that the 9 synonymous divergence between the bat derived viruses and SARS-CoV-2 is larger than 10 between GD410721 and SARS-CoV-2 in the RBD, providing strong additional support for 11 the recombination hypothesis. However, the synonymous divergence between pangolin 12 strain and SARS-CoV-2 is also relatively high, which is not consistent with a recent 13 recombination between them, instead it suggests a recombination into RaTG13. We also 14 find a 14-fold increase in the d N /d S ratio from the lineage leading to SARS-CoV-2 to the 15 strains of the current pandemic, suggesting that the vast majority of non-synonymous 16 mutations currently segregating within the human strains have a negative impact on viral 17 fitness. Finally, we estimate that the time to the most recent common ancestor of SARS-18

CoV-2 and RaTG13 or RmYN02 based on synonymous divergence, is 51.71 years (95% 19 a coronavirus (Lu, et al. 2020; Zhang and Holmes 2020), Severe acute respiratory syndrome 1 coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), an RNA virus with a 29,891 bp genome consisting of four major 2 structural genes Zhou, Yang, et al. 2020). Of particular relevance to this study 3 is the spike protein which is responsible for binding to the primary receptor for the virus, 4 angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) (Wan, et al. 2020; Zhou, Yang, et al. 5 2020). 6
Human SARS-CoV-2 is related to a coronavirus (RaTG13) isolated from the bat 7
Rhinolophus affinis from Yunnan province of China (Zhou, Yang, et al. 2020). RaTG13 and the 8 human strain reference sequence (Genbank accession number MN996532) are 96.2% identical 9

and it was first argued that, throughout the genome, RaTG13 is the closest relative to human 10 SARS-CoV-2 (Zhou, et al. 2020 showed that RaTG13 and SARS-CoV-2 11 were 91.02% and 90.55% identical ,respectively, to coronaviruses isolated from pangolins 12 (Pangolin-CoV), which therefore form a close outgroup to the SARS-CoV-2+RaTG13 clade . 13 Furthermore, five key amino acids in the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of spike were identical 14 between SARS-CoV-2 and Pangolin-CoV, but differed between those two strains and RaTG13. 15 (Lam, et al. 2020) independently made similar observations and additionally showed that when 16 analyzing a window of length 582bp in the RBD, nonsynonymous mutations support a 17 phylogenetic tree with SARS-CoV-2 and Pangolin-CoV as sister-groups, while synonymous 18 mutations do not. They discuss two possible explanations for their results, one which includes 19 recombination and another which includes selection-driven convergent evolution. Boni, et al. 20 2020 found little evidence of recombination between SARS-CoV-2 and Pangolin-CoV using the 21 recombination analysis software 3SEQ (Lam, et al. 2018), but argued that if there has been 22 recombination, it likely occurred into RaTG13 from an unknown divergent source. This would 23 explain the amino acid similarity between SARS-CoV-2 and Pangolin-CoV in the RBD as an 24
ancestral trait that has been lost (by recombination) in RaTG13. Using a phylogenetic analysis 25 they also dated the RaTG13 and SARS-CoV-2 divergence to be between 40 to 70 years. 26

TABREF1.text: The mosaic pattern that different regions of the genome show highest identity to different virus 9 strains is likely to have been caused by the rich recombination history of the SARS-CoV-2 10 lineage (Boni, et al. 2020; Patiño-Galindo, et al. 2020). Moreover, its unique connection with 11 SARS-CoV related lineages in some genomic regions may suggest recombination between the 12 ancestral lineage of SARS-CoV-2 and distantly related virus lineages, although more formal 13 analyses are needed to determine the recombination history (see also Boni, et al. 2020 for 14 further discussion). Searching databases with BLAST using the most closely related viral 15 strains, RaTG13 and RmYN02, we observe a very similar pattern, as that observed for SARS-16CoV-2, in terms of top hits across the genome(Fig. 1B), suggesting that these possible 17 recombination events with distantly related lineages are not unique to the SARS-CoV-2 lineage, 18 but happened on the ancestral lineage of both SARS-CoV-2, RaTG13, and RmYN02. The 95% confidence intervals, calculated based on 1,000 bootstrap replicates, are included in the brackets for each estimates.
